questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
Drag and drop the multicast concepts from the left onto the correct descriptions on the right.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content:
The correct order:
DM
IGMP
SM
shared
source

I suggest: “Technology that requires an RP” – “PIM-SM”
“technology that uses the RP as the single common root” – “shared tree”

Def. from cisco book: “Shared tree: A shared tree is a single tree that is shared between all sources for each multicast group. The shared tree has a single common root, called a Rendezvous Point (RP)”.
Def. from Wikipedia: “PIM Sparse Mode (PIM-SM) explicitly builds unidirectional shared trees rooted at a rendezvous point (RP) per group”

DM
IGMP
SM
SHARED
SOURCE

in case of PIM SSM (source Specific Multicast) although we enable PIM SM Sparse Mode , but we do not use RP as the common root. so "Technology that requires an RP "is not always PIM-SM, but "technology that uses the RP as the single common root " is PIM-SM and the "technology that requires RP" is "shared tree".

https://packetlife.net/blog/2008/oct/20/pim-sm-source-versus-shared-trees/
correct is to swap 3 with 4

yep I agree with both of you:

1-2
2-1
3-3
4-4
5-5

i'm go with blizzlondon 
An RP is required only in networks running PIM SM

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which command is used to complete this configuration for QoS class-based marking?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The name of the policy is "mark", so if wen need to mark (actually remark) the traffic, then A is the answer.

questions.question_text: What causes multicast traffic to permanently stay on the shared tree and not switch to the source tree?

discussion.content:
I think C is correct:

ip pim spt-threshold {kbps| infinity}[group-list access-list]
Specifying the infinity keyword causes the router never to move to the shortest-path tree; it remains on the shared tree. This keyword applies to a multicast environment of "many-to-many" communication.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipmulti_optim/configuration/12-4t/imc-optim-12-4t-book/imc_pim_sparse.html
Network administrators can force traffic to stay on the shared tree by using the Cisco IOS ip pim spt-threshold infinity command.

Selected Answer: C
C is correc
I agree with you. C should be the right answer

Selected Answer: C
Like the others pointed out C is correct, Search the doc for infinity.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/solutions_docs/ip_multicast/White_papers/mcst_ovr.html

IOS command: ip pim spt-threshold {kbps| infinity}[group-list acl-name]
IOS XR command: spt-threshold infinity [group-list acl-name] 
The infinity keyword will cause all the sources for the specified group to never switch over to an SPT and continue using the shared tree.
Answer C

Yes I agree with C.

"If the shared tree is not an optimal path between the source and the receiver, the routers dynamically create a source tree and stop traffic from flowing down the shared tree. This behavior is the default behavior in software. Network administrators can force traffic to stay on the shared tree by using the ip pim spt-threshold infinity command."

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipmulti_pim/configuration/xe-16/imc-pim-xe-16-book/imc-tech-oview.html

choices.D: The RP IP address is configured incorrectly
choices.C: The SPT threshold is set to infinity
choices.B: The RP announcements are being filtered

questions.question_text: Which additional feature does MPLS DiffServ tunneling support?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Diffserv Tunneling Modes introduces a new Per-Hop-Behavior (PHB), which allows differentiated QoS in a providers network. 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/multiprotocol-label-switching-mpls/mpls/47815-diffserv-tunnel.html

Which additional feature does MPLS DiffServ tunneling support?
The following features are supported on MPLS DiffServ Tunneling Modes: MPLS per-hop behavior (PHB) layer management. There is improved scalability of the MPLS layer management by control on managed customer edge (CE) routers. MPLS can “tunnel” a packet's QoS (that is, the QoS is transparent from edge to edge)

A cannot be correct. "The MPLS experimental (MPLS EXP) field can be marked differently and independently of the PHB marked in the IP Precedence or differentiated services code point (DSCP) field."

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/mp_te_diffserv/configuration/15-mt/mp-te-diffserv-15-mt-book/mp-diffserv-tun-mode.html
Agreed, A is correct
A is correct

choices.C: using GRE tunnels to hide markings

choices.D: R2 is elected as the RP for this domain
choices.C: R2 floods information about R1 throughout the multicast domain
choices.B: R1 floods information about R2 throughout the multicast domain
choices.A: R2 is unable to share information because the ip pim autorp listener command is missing

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. An engineer configured multicast routing on client's network. What is the effect of this multicast implementation?

discussion.content:
C is correct.
Since BSR is enable on R2 therefore:
 A BSR is elected among the candidate BSRs automatically; they use bootstrap messages to discover which BSR has the highest priority. This router then announces to all PIM routers in the PIM domain that it is the BSR.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipmulti_pim/configuration/xe-16-5/imc-pim-xe-16-5-book/imc-basic-cfg.html#GUID-D1656247-AFA8-4F67-8114-FB290E579FDD

Selected Answer: C
C is right

C is the way to go 
BSR (Bootstrap) is similar to Cisco’s AutoRP, it’s a protocol that we use to automatically find the RP (Rendezvous Point) in our multicast network. BSR however, is a standard and included in PIMv2, unlike AutoRP which is a Cisco proprietary protocol.

BSR uses two roles:

Candidate BSR: this is the router that collects information from all available RPs in the network and advertises is throughout the network. It’s function is similar to the mapping agent in AutoRP.
Candidate RP: these are routers that are advertising themselves who want to become the RP.
Credits go to networklessons.com
C is wrong. A is right answer. For Auto-RP to work in sparse mode, autorp-listener must be configured.

comments.content: You Wrong. This config is abour BSR . See the config is about RP-Candidate and Candidate-BSR. You don't need ip pim autorp listener in this scenario, only if you use AUTO-RP

Yeap... 'C' is better.

PIM uses the BSR to discover and announce RP-set information for each group prefix to all the routers in a PIM domain. This is the same function performed by Auto-RP, but the BSR is part of the PIM Version 2 specification. The BSR mechanism interoperates with Auto-RP on Cisco routers.

To avoid a single point of failure, you can configure several candidate BSRs in a PIM domain. A BSR is elected among the candidate BSRs automatically; they use bootstrap messages to discover which BSR has the highest priority. This router then announces to all PIM routers in the PIM domain that it is the BSR.

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipmulti_pim/configuration/xe-16-5/imc-pim-xe-16-5-book/imc-basic-cfg.html#GUID-D1656247-AFA8-4F67-8114-FB290E579FDD
you are talking about AUTO-RP... don´t be confused, this questions presents BSR configuration

Just to clarify. Candidate RP Announcement Msgs are shared with the Mappings Agents via 224.0.1.39. Downstream routers will listen for the Discovery Msgs 224.0.1.40 from Mapping Agent, which R1 is not originating as R1 is only configured to be a Candidate RP.

It is acceptable to use the same interface address Candidate RP and Mapping Agent, but this is not the case here.
